substances.name: DMAA
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA banned DMAA as an unsafe food additive (April 2013). Classified as illegal dietary supplement ingredient. WADA prohibited since 2010. Multiple court challenges (Hi-Tech vs FDA) rejected through Supreme Court (2020).

stateRestrictions.US: Federal ban - illegal in all dietary supplements

healthRisks.description: At least 5 documented deaths directly attributed to DMAA, including Claire Squires (London Marathon 2012), PFC Michael Sparling (Fort Bliss 2011), and Sgt Demekia Cola (Fort Bliss 2011).
5+ documented cases of intracerebral hemorrhage in users aged 21-41, often within hours of DMAA consumption. BP readings as high as 240/120 mmHg recorded.
Multiple case reports of myocardial infarction, cardiac arrest, and arrhythmias in young, previously healthy individuals.
Systolic BP increases of 8-16 mmHg at normal doses; case reports show BP as high as 240/120 mmHg in overdose situations.

contraindications: Any heart condition or cardiovascular disease
substances.description: DMAA (1,3-dimethylamylamine) is a synthetic sympathomimetic amine originally developed by Eli Lilly in 1944 as a nasal decongestant (Forthane). It gained widespread popularity in pre-workout supplements like Jack3d and OxyElite Pro between 2006-2013, often marketed falsely as 'geranium extract.' Despite manufacturer claims of natural origin, extensive laboratory analysis confirmed DMAA is entirely synthetic. The FDA banned DMAA in 2013 after receiving 86 adverse event reports including at least 5 deaths. Court challenges by Hi-Tech Pharmaceuticals were rejected through the Supreme Court in 2020, definitively establishing DMAA's illegal status.
substances.mechanism: DMAA is a sympathomimetic amine that primarily functions as a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor/releasing agent (Ki ~649 nM at NET). It also competitively inhibits the dopamine transporter (DAT) with IC50 ~29.4 µM—approximately 60x less potent than amphetamine. DMAA causes vasoconstriction, elevated blood pressure, and increased heart rate through sympathetic nervous system activation. Unlike amphetamine, DMAA lacks a phenyl ring, which reduces DAT potency but maintains sympathomimetic activity. Terminal half-life is 8.45 hours with minimal hepatic metabolism (>90% excreted unchanged in urine).
substances.history: 1944: Synthesized by Eli Lilly as nasal decongestant. 1948-1983: Marketed as Forthane/Forthan. 1983: Voluntarily withdrawn due to side effects. 2006: Re-emerged in supplements falsely claimed as 'geranium extract.' 2010: WADA prohibition. 2011: Fort Bliss soldier deaths prompt Army investigation. 2012: FDA warning letters to 10+ companies; UK/Australia bans. 2013: FDA declares illegal; USPlabs destroys $8M inventory. 2017-2020: Hi-Tech vs FDA lawsuit rejected through Supreme Court.
substances.whyBanned: FDA determined DMAA poses unacceptable cardiovascular risks even at recommended doses. Key factors: (1) 5+ documented deaths including young athletes; (2) 86 serious adverse event reports including strokes, heart attacks, and seizures; (3) Synthetic origin despite natural marketing claims; (4) 92.3% of military false positive amphetamine tests caused by DMAA; (5) Hi-Tech vs FDA litigation confirmed DMAA is not a dietary ingredient and lacks safety evidence.

pillarSections.title: What is DMAA?
pillarSections.content:
DMAA (1,3-Dimethylamylamine) is a synthetic sympathomimetic amine with the chemical formula C₇H₁₇N (molecular weight 115.22 g/mol). Originally developed by Eli Lilly in 1944 as a nasal decongestant under the brand name Forthane, DMAA was voluntarily withdrawn from the pharmaceutical market in 1983 due to side effects.

In 2006, DMAA re-emerged in dietary supplements marketed as a 'natural' extract from geranium plants. However, extensive scientific analysis by NSF International, the University of Milan, and the FDA definitively established that DMAA is entirely synthetic—not derived from any botanical source. The 'geranium extract' claim was fraudulent marketing used to circumvent dietary supplement regulations.

DMAA gained massive popularity in pre-workout supplements like Jack3d and OxyElite Pro between 2006-2013 due to its potent stimulant effects, including increased energy, focus, and euphoria. At peak popularity, DMAA-containing products generated hundreds of millions in sales.

pillarSections.title: Why Was DMAA Banned?
pillarSections.content:
The FDA banned DMAA in April 2013 after receiving 86 reports of serious adverse events, including at least 5 confirmed deaths. Key reasons for the ban include:

  • Deaths: Claire Squires (30) died during the 2012 London Marathon; PFC Michael Sparling (22) and Sgt Demekia Cola (32) died during training at Fort Bliss in 2011
  • Cardiovascular Events: Multiple heart attacks, strokes, and cardiac arrests in young, healthy individuals
  • Hemorrhagic Strokes: 5+ documented cases of brain hemorrhages in users aged 21-41
  • Synthetic Origin: Laboratory analysis proved DMAA is not a natural botanical ingredient, making it illegal under DSHEA
  • Court Confirmation: Hi-Tech Pharmaceuticals challenged the ban through the Supreme Court (2020)—all appeals were denied, confirming DMAA's illegal status

In 2013, USPlabs voluntarily destroyed approximately $8 million in Jack3d and OxyElite Pro inventory containing DMAA.

pillarSections.title: DMAA Side Effects: Short-Term & Long-Term Risks
pillarSections.content:
Acute (Short-Term) Side Effects:

  • Blood pressure elevation: 8-16 mmHg increase (up to 240/120 mmHg in overdose)
  • Rapid heartbeat and heart palpitations
  • Severe headaches (often prodromal to stroke)
  • Tremors and involuntary muscle twitching
  • Anxiety, agitation, and restlessness
  • Nausea and stomach discomfort
  • Excessive sweating

Severe/Life-Threatening Effects:

  • Hemorrhagic stroke: 5+ documented cases in young users
  • Heart attack (myocardial infarction)
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Seizures
  • Acute liver failure (documented in OxyElite Pro outbreak)

Long-Term Risks:

Due to DMAA's ban, long-term studies are limited. However, repeated cardiovascular stress from stimulant abuse can contribute to:

  • Chronic hypertension
  • Heart muscle damage
  • Increased stroke risk
  • Potential CYP2D6 enzyme inhibition affecting other medications
pillarSections.keywordTarget: dmaa pre workout side effects long term

pillarSections.title: How Long Does DMAA Stay in Your System?
pillarSections.content:
DMAA has a terminal half-life of 8.45 ± 1.9 hours—meaning it takes about 8.5 hours for half the dose to be eliminated. Key pharmacokinetic data:

ParameterValue
Half-Life8.45 hours (range: 6.57-11.79 hours)
Peak Concentration3-5 hours after ingestion
Volume of Distribution236 L (extensive tissue distribution)
MetabolismMinimal—90%+ excreted unchanged in urine

Detection Windows by Test Type:

  • Urine: 4-7 days (up to 105 hours documented)
  • Blood: 24-48 hours
  • Hair: Up to 90 days
  • Saliva: 1-3 days (limited data)

DMAA's large volume of distribution (236 L) means it accumulates extensively in tissues, contributing to the extended detection window despite moderate clearance rates.

pillarSections.title: DMAA Drug Testing: False Positives & Detection
pillarSections.content:
Critical Warning: DMAA causes false positive results for amphetamines on standard immunoassay drug tests.

Military research revealed that 92.3% of false-positive amphetamine samples in Department of Defense testing contained DMAA. Of 134 false-positive samples analyzed, 124 were caused by DMAA at ~6.0 mg/L concentration.

Why False Positives Occur:

Immunoassay screening tests (EMIT) lack specificity and cross-react with DMAA's sympathomimetic structure, flagging it as amphetamine. However, confirmatory GC-MS testing correctly identifies DMAA and distinguishes it from actual amphetamines.

How to Handle a False Positive:

  1. Request GC-MS confirmatory testing immediately
  2. Disclose any supplements containing DMAA (or contaminated products)
  3. Provide supplement labels/receipts as documentation
  4. Request Medical Review Officer (MRO) evaluation

The Air Force Drug Testing Laboratory confirms: under GC-MS testing, DMAA will never produce a positive result for amphetamines.

faqs.question: Is DMAA legal in 2025?
faqs.answer: No. DMAA is illegal in the United States and banned in most countries including the UK, Australia, Canada, and throughout the EU. The FDA's ban was upheld through the Supreme Court in 2020. Any product containing DMAA is considered an adulterated dietary supplement under federal law.

faqs.question: How long does DMAA stay in your system?
faqs.answer: DMAA has a half-life of 8.45 hours. It's detectable in urine for 4-7 days (up to 105 hours with sensitive testing), in blood for 24-48 hours, and in hair for up to 90 days. Over 90% is excreted unchanged in urine.

faqs.question: Does DMAA cause false positive drug tests?
faqs.answer: Yes. DMAA causes false positives for amphetamines on immunoassay screening tests. Military data shows 92.3% of false-positive amphetamine samples contained DMAA. However, confirmatory GC-MS testing correctly distinguishes DMAA from amphetamines.

faqs.question: Why was DMAA banned?
faqs.answer: The FDA banned DMAA after 86 adverse event reports including at least 5 deaths. Key reasons include documented fatalities in young athletes, hemorrhagic strokes, heart attacks, and proof that DMAA is synthetic (not natural geranium extract as marketed).

faqs.question: What are safe legal alternatives to DMAA?
faqs.answer: Legal alternatives include caffeine (for energy), citrulline malate (for pumps and performance), beta-alanine (for endurance), and L-theanine combined with caffeine (for focused energy without jitters). These ingredients are FDA-compliant with established safety profiles.

faqs.question: Can DMAA cause a stroke?
faqs.answer: Yes. There are at least 5 documented cases of hemorrhagic stroke (brain bleeding) in DMAA users aged 21-41. DMAA causes severe blood pressure elevation—readings as high as 240/120 mmHg have been documented in overdose cases.

substances.name: Phenibut
substances.legalStatusDetails: Banned as dietary supplement ingredient (April 2019). Schedule II in Alabama. Sold only as 'research chemical' online.

healthRisks.description: 1,320 poison center cases reported (2009-2019), sharp increase 2015-2019. 3 deaths, 80 comas documented.
sources: American Association of Poison Control Centers

healthRisks.description: Severe withdrawal syndrome similar to alcohol/benzodiazepine withdrawal - can cause seizures, psychosis, and death.
Physical dependence can develop in as little as 2-3 weeks of daily use at doses over 1g/day.

substances.description: Phenibut (β-Phenyl-γ-aminobutyric acid) is a synthetic GABA analogue developed in the Soviet Union that acts primarily as a GABA-B receptor agonist. It produces anxiolytic and sedative effects but carries extremely high risks of dependence and a severe, potentially life-threatening withdrawal syndrome similar to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal.
substances.mechanism: Acts as a GABA-B receptor agonist and α2δ voltage-gated calcium channel ligand. The phenyl ring allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier more efficiently than GABA itself. Also binds α2δ subunit similar to gabapentin. Plasma half-life approximately 5.3 hours, but effects last 15-24 hours.
substances.history: Developed in the Soviet Union (Leningrad) in the 1960s as a neuropsychotropic agent for cosmonauts to manage stress and anxiety without impairing cognitive function. Still used as a prescription medicine in Russia, Ukraine, and Latvia under names like Noofen and Citrocard. Never approved for medical use in Western countries.
substances.whyBanned: FDA issued warning letters in April 2019 determining phenibut does not meet the statutory definition of a dietary ingredient. The severe risk of dependence, potentially fatal withdrawal syndrome (with seizures and psychosis), and lack of proven efficacy led to its effective ban from dietary supplements. It's now only sold illegally as a 'research chemical.'

pillarSections.title: What is Phenibut? Soviet Origins & How It Works
pillarSections.content:
Phenibut (β-Phenyl-γ-aminobutyric acid) is a synthetic derivative of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA, developed in the Soviet Union in the 1960s. Unlike GABA itself, phenibut's phenyl ring allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier efficiently.

How Phenibut Works in the Brain

Phenibut acts through two primary mechanisms:

  • GABA-B Receptor Agonism: Produces anxiolytic (anti-anxiety) and sedative effects similar to baclofen and GHB
  • α2δ Calcium Channel Binding: Similar to gabapentin/pregabalin, contributing to its calming effects

The R-isomer of phenibut has approximately 5-fold higher affinity for α2δ than for GABA-B receptors, making its mechanism more complex than simple GABA enhancement.

Pharmacokinetics

ParameterValue
Plasma Half-Life~5.3 hours
Duration of Effects15-24 hours (subjective)
Brain Penetration~0.1% of dose reaches brain
Excretion63-65% unchanged in urine

Warning: Despite the relatively short half-life, phenibut's effects persist much longer than plasma levels suggest, and dependence develops rapidly with daily use.

pillarSections.title: Why FDA Banned Phenibut (2019 Warning Letters)
pillarSections.content:
On April 10-16, 2019, the FDA issued warning letters to multiple companies marketing products containing phenibut as dietary supplements, effectively banning it from the legitimate supplement market.

FDA's Legal Determination

The FDA determined that phenibut:

  • Does not meet the statutory definition of a dietary ingredient under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
  • Products containing phenibut are adulterated and misbranded
  • Has no recognized medical use in the United States
  • Poses serious safety risks including dependence and life-threatening withdrawal

Enforcement Actions

FDA warning letters were sent to companies including:

  • American Made Nutrition LLC
  • Bulk Stimulants
  • SL Nutrition, Inc.
  • Various online retailers

Following FDA action, major retailers removed phenibut products. However, it remains available from 'research chemical' vendors operating in a legal gray area.

State-Level Actions

StateStatus
AlabamaSchedule II Controlled Substance
KentuckyControlled substance restrictions

More states are expected to schedule phenibut as awareness of its dangers grows.

pillarSections.title: Phenibut Withdrawal Syndrome: Symptoms & Severity
pillarSections.content:
Phenibut withdrawal is a medical emergency that can be life-threatening. The syndrome resembles severe alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, with documented cases of seizures, psychosis, and deaths.

Withdrawal Timeline

PhaseTimelineKey Symptoms
Early2-24 hoursAnxiety, tremor, palpitations, insomnia, sweating
Acute PeakDays 1-3Severe anxiety, psychosis, hallucinations, seizures, autonomic instability
SubacuteDays 4-14Persistent insomnia, anxiety waves, depression, cognitive fog
Protracted (PAWS)Weeks to monthsIntermittent anxiety, sleep disruption, mood instability

Most Dangerous Symptoms

  • Seizures: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures can occur, especially with abrupt cessation
  • Psychosis: Visual/auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, inability to recognize reality
  • Autonomic Instability: Severe tachycardia, hypertension, fever, diaphoresis
  • Suicidal Ideation: Profound dysphoria and hopelessness

2024 Systematic Review Findings

A comprehensive review of 15 documented phenibut withdrawal cases found:

  • Doses ranged from 1g/day to over 30g/day
  • Duration of use from 2 weeks to several years
  • Most required hospitalization, some in ICU
  • 92.3% presented with psychomotor agitation

Never stop phenibut cold turkey. Abrupt cessation from daily use can trigger life-threatening withdrawal.

pillarSections.title: Phenibut Drug Testing & Detection Windows
pillarSections.content:
Phenibut is not detected on standard drug tests including typical employment and clinical screening panels. However, specialized testing can identify it.

Detection Methods

Test TypeDetects Phenibut?Notes
Standard Urine Panel (5/10/12)NoTests for opioids, benzos, THC, cocaine, etc.
Immunoassay ScreeningNoNo cross-reactivity with tested substances
LC-MS/MS (specialized)YesRequires specific order, forensic/toxicology labs
GC-MS (specialized)YesGold standard confirmation method

Detection Windows

Based on phenibut's pharmacokinetics (5.3-hour half-life, renal excretion):

  • Blood: 24-48 hours after typical doses
  • Urine: 1-2 days after therapeutic doses; potentially longer with chronic heavy use
  • Hair: Theoretically detectable but rarely tested

When Testing May Occur

Specialized phenibut testing may be ordered in:

  • Emergency departments when phenibut use is suspected
  • Addiction treatment intake assessments
  • Forensic toxicology investigations
  • Research studies on GABAergic substances

Important: Even though phenibut won't trigger a standard drug test, its withdrawal can be medically dangerous. Be honest with healthcare providers about use.

pillarSections.title: Phenibut Legal Status 2025: US & International
pillarSections.content:
United States Federal Status (2025)

Phenibut occupies a legal gray area at the federal level:

  • Not FDA-approved as a drug or dietary supplement ingredient
  • Not scheduled under the Controlled Substances Act (possession is not federally criminal)
  • Cannot be legally sold as a dietary supplement (per 2019 FDA determination)
  • Available only as a 'research chemical' from specialty vendors

pillarSections.title: Safe Legal Alternatives to Phenibut
pillarSections.content:
If you're seeking anxiety relief or better sleep without phenibut's dangerous dependency risks, these evidence-based alternatives are legal and much safer:

For Anxiety

1. L-Theanine

  • Mechanism: Amino acid from tea that increases alpha-wave activity and modulates glutamate/GABA
  • Evidence: Clinical trials show reduced physiological and subjective stress; 400mg/day effective for anxiety
  • Safety: Well-tolerated up to 900mg/day with minimal side effects
  • Dosage: 100-400mg daily

2. Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera)

  • Mechanism: Adaptogenic herb that modulates cortisol and HPA-axis activity
  • Evidence: Multiple RCTs show significant anxiety and stress reduction at 300-600mg/day
  • Safety: Generally well-tolerated; avoid in pregnancy and autoimmune conditions
  • Dosage: 300-600mg standardized extract daily

For Sleep

3. Magnesium Glycinate

  • Mechanism: Essential mineral that modulates GABA signaling and is required for serotonin synthesis
  • Evidence: 2025 RCT showed improved insomnia scores within 2 weeks at 250mg elemental magnesium
  • Safety: Safe for most; avoid high doses with kidney disease
  • Dosage: 200-400mg elemental magnesium before bed

4. Glycine

  • Mechanism: Inhibitory amino acid that lowers core body temperature and promotes sleep
  • Evidence: RCTs show 3g before bed improves sleep quality and reduces next-day fatigue
  • Safety: Well-tolerated with no dependence risk

When to Seek Medical Help

If you have persistent anxiety lasting weeks, significant daily impairment, or history of substance use, consult a physician. Prescription options like SSRIs/SNRIs may be more appropriate than supplements.

faqs.question: How long does phenibut withdrawal last?
faqs.answer: Acute phenibut withdrawal typically peaks within 1-3 days and improves over 1-2 weeks with treatment. However, protracted withdrawal symptoms (PAWS) including anxiety, insomnia, and mood instability can persist for weeks to months, especially after heavy or prolonged use. The 2024 systematic review found most cases resolved within 5-14 days with medical management.

faqs.question: Can phenibut withdrawal cause seizures?
faqs.answer: Yes, phenibut withdrawal can cause life-threatening seizures, especially with abrupt cessation after daily use. The mechanism is similar to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal - sudden removal of GABAergic activity leads to CNS hyperexcitability. This is why medical supervision and gradual tapering are essential. Never stop phenibut cold turkey.

faqs.question: Is phenibut legal in the United States?
faqs.answer: Phenibut is in a legal gray area in the US. It's not federally scheduled (possession isn't criminal), but the FDA determined in 2019 that it cannot be legally sold as a dietary supplement. It's only available as a 'research chemical.' Alabama has scheduled it as a controlled substance, and other states may follow.

faqs.question: Does phenibut show up on a drug test?
faqs.answer: No, phenibut is not detected on standard drug tests including 5-panel, 10-panel, and 12-panel urine screens. It requires specialized testing (LC-MS/MS or GC-MS) that is only available at forensic or specialized toxicology laboratories and must be specifically ordered.

faqs.question: How do you safely taper off phenibut?
faqs.answer: Safe phenibut tapering typically involves reducing doses by 50-100mg (5-10%) every 1-2 weeks, with slower reductions as doses get lower. Many clinicians prefer cross-tapering to baclofen (approximately 10mg baclofen per 1g phenibut) which can then be tapered more controllably. Always consult a physician experienced with GABAergic withdrawal.

faqs.question: What does phenibut withdrawal feel like?
faqs.answer: Phenibut withdrawal typically causes severe anxiety, insomnia, tremor, rapid heartbeat, sweating, and agitation. In severe cases, it can cause visual and auditory hallucinations, psychosis, paranoid delusions, and seizures. Many describe it as one of the worst withdrawal experiences, comparable to severe alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal.

faqs.question: Can you die from phenibut withdrawal?
faqs.answer: Yes, phenibut withdrawal can be fatal. Deaths have occurred from seizures, aspiration during psychosis, self-harm during severe dysphoria, and cardiovascular complications from autonomic instability. This is why phenibut withdrawal should be treated as a medical emergency and never attempted without professional supervision.

faqs.question: Why is phenibut so addictive?
faqs.answer: Phenibut is highly addictive because it acts on GABA-B receptors (similar to alcohol and GHB) and tolerance develops rapidly - often within 2-3 weeks of daily use. Users need increasing doses to achieve the same effect, and the brain becomes dependent on phenibut to maintain normal GABAergic function. Stopping triggers severe rebound anxiety and physical withdrawal.

faqs.question: What is the best natural alternative to phenibut?
faqs.answer: The best evidence-based alternatives are L-theanine (100-400mg) for daytime anxiety, ashwagandha (300-600mg) for stress reduction, and magnesium glycinate (200-400mg) for sleep. These have clinical evidence for efficacy without the severe dependence and withdrawal risks of phenibut. For significant anxiety, consult a physician about prescription options.

faqs.question: How quickly can you become dependent on phenibut?
faqs.answer: Physical dependence on phenibut can develop in as little as 2-3 weeks of daily use, especially at doses above 1g/day. Tolerance often develops within the first week, leading to dose escalation. Case reports document severe withdrawal in users who took phenibut for only 2 weeks. The dependence liability is significantly higher than most OTC supplements.

substances.name: Kratom
substances.legalStatusDetails: Not federally scheduled but under FDA Import Alert 54-15. Banned in 7 states including the 2025 Louisiana Ban (SB 154, effective Aug 1, 2025). Texas Regulation (SB 1868, effective Sept 1, 2025) imposes the nation's strictest 7-OH limits at 0.1%. FDA recommended scheduling 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH) in July 2025. 15+ states have adopted the Kratom Consumer Protection Act (KCPA) with age restrictions and testing requirements.

stateRestrictions.Louisiana: Schedule I - SB 154 Ban (Aug 1, 2025) - $50K fine, 1-5 years for distribution
stateRestrictions.Texas: KCPA - SB 1868 (Sept 1, 2025) - Strictest 7-OH limit at 0.1%, age 21+

healthRisks.description: CDC documented 91 overdose deaths involving kratom (2016-2017). Most cases involved other substances, but kratom was the sole toxicological finding in some fatalities.
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine act on mu-opioid receptors, creating physical dependence. Withdrawal symptoms include muscle aches, insomnia, irritability, and anxiety lasting 4-10 days.
Analysis of Poison Control data (2011-2017) identified 113 kratom-induced seizures. Risk increases with concentrated 7-OH products.
199 people infected in 2018 Salmonella outbreak linked to kratom. Products often contaminated with bacteria, heavy metals, and in some cases synthetic opioids.
Rare cases of liver injury documented in chronic users. Mechanism may involve CYP enzyme inhibition or direct hepatocellular toxicity.

sideEffects: Opioid-like withdrawal syndrome (muscle aches, insomnia, RLS)
Seizures (especially with high doses or 7-OH products)
Rapid tolerance development requiring dose escalation
contraindications: Liver disease or elevated liver enzymes
Concurrent use of CNS depressants (benzos, alcohol, opioids)
substances.description: Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a tropical evergreen tree native to Southeast Asia whose leaves contain alkaloids that act on opioid receptors. The two primary alkaloids—mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH)—produce dose-dependent effects: stimulation at low doses (1-5g) and sedation/analgesia at higher doses (5-15g). While marketed as a 'natural' alternative to opioids, kratom produces physiological dependence with a documented withdrawal syndrome. The FDA maintains Import Alert 54-15 and has not approved kratom for any medical use.
substances.mechanism: Mitragynine is a partial agonist at mu-opioid receptors with additional activity at kappa, delta opioid receptors, alpha-2 adrenergic receptors, and serotonergic systems. 7-hydroxymitragynine is approximately 22x more potent at mu-opioid receptors. This multi-receptor activity explains kratom's unique combination of stimulant (low dose) and sedative (high dose) effects, as well as its complex withdrawal presentation combining opioid-like and stimulant-like features.
substances.history: Traditional use in Thailand and Malaysia for centuries as a labor aid and folk medicine. Thailand banned kratom in 1943 due to interference with opium tax revenue, then decriminalized it in 2021. In the US, kratom gained popularity in the 2010s as an alternative to prescription opioids. The DEA attempted emergency Schedule I classification in 2016 but withdrew after unprecedented public backlash. Multiple contamination outbreaks, overdose deaths, and wrongful death lawsuits have driven increasing state-level regulation.
substances.whyBanned: States ban kratom due to: (1) Opioid-like addiction and withdrawal potential; (2) 91+ documented deaths involving kratom; (3) Contamination issues including the 2018 Salmonella outbreak; (4) Lack of quality control and standardization; (5) FDA's determination that kratom products are adulterated/misbranded; (6) Emerging evidence of seizure risk with concentrated 7-OH products.

pillarSections.title: What is Kratom?
pillarSections.content:
Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a tropical evergreen tree in the coffee family native to Southeast Asia, primarily Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Myanmar. The leaves contain over 40 alkaloids, with the two most pharmacologically significant being mitragynine (66% of alkaloid content) and 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH).

Kratom produces dose-dependent effects:

  • Low doses (1-5g): Stimulation, increased energy, alertness, and sociability—similar to coffee
  • Moderate doses (5-10g): Analgesic effects, mild euphoria, reduced anxiety
  • High doses (10-15g+): Sedation, opioid-like effects, pain relief, potential for nausea

This biphasic action results from mitragynine's complex pharmacology: at low concentrations it activates adrenergic receptors (stimulation), while at higher concentrations mu-opioid receptor activity predominates (sedation/analgesia).

Common Forms:

  • Powder: Dried, crushed leaves—most common form
  • Capsules: Measured powder doses for convenience
  • Extracts: Concentrated products with elevated 7-OH levels—higher addiction and seizure risk
  • Shots/Drinks: Liquid extracts often sold at gas stations

While kratom has been used traditionally in Southeast Asia for centuries, its modern Western use as an opioid alternative has raised significant safety concerns, leading to FDA import alerts and state-level bans.

pillarSections.title: Kratom Legal Status 2025: State-by-State Map
pillarSections.content:
Kratom's legal status varies dramatically across the United States. As of November 2025, 7 states have fully banned kratom, while 15+ states have adopted the Kratom Consumer Protection Act (KCPA) with age restrictions and product standards.

2025 Major Legislative Changes

StateBillEffective DateKey Provisions
LouisianaSB 154Aug 1, 2025Schedule I ban. $50,000 fine and 1-5 years for distribution. Possession: $1,000 or 6 months.
TexasSB 1868Sept 1, 2025Strictest 7-OH limit in nation (0.1%). Age 21+. Synthetic alkaloids banned under Penalty Group 1.
GeorgiaHB 181Jan 1, 2025Age raised to 21+. Strict labeling requirements. Vaping kratom prohibited.
South CarolinaSB 221July 2025KCPA framework with safety and labeling standards.
OklahomaSB 8912025Age 18+. Max 2% 7-OH. Lab testing required.

Fully Banned States (7)

Alabama, Arkansas, Indiana, Rhode Island, Vermont, Wisconsin, Louisiana (as of Aug 2025)

In these states, kratom is classified as a Schedule I controlled substance. Possession and sale carry criminal penalties.

KCPA Regulation States (15+)

States with Kratom Consumer Protection Acts regulate rather than ban: Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Maryland, Nevada, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia

KCPA typically requires: age verification (18-21+), lab testing, labeling of alkaloid content, prohibition on synthetic alkaloids, and GMP manufacturing standards.

Federal Status

Kratom remains not scheduled at the federal level. However, the FDA maintains Import Alert 54-15 allowing seizure of kratom products at ports. In July 2025, the FDA recommended scheduling 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH) as a controlled substance—this targets concentrated extract products, not natural leaf kratom.

pillarSections.title: Kratom Withdrawal: Timeline & The 10% Taper Protocol
pillarSections.content:
Never quit kratom cold turkey if you have significant dependence. Abrupt cessation causes uncomfortable withdrawal symptoms that peak around days 3-4.

Withdrawal Timeline

PhaseDurationSymptoms
Early Withdrawal6-12 hoursMild irritability, anxiety, muscle aches, sweating, runny nose
Acute Withdrawal24-72 hoursPeak physical symptoms, intense muscle pain, severe GI distress, insomnia, RLS
Subacute PhaseDays 4-7Gradual symptom reduction, lingering fatigue, reduced psychological intensity
Late Withdrawal1-2 weeksMost physical symptoms resolved, psychological symptoms may persist
PAWSWeeks to monthsMood instability, anxiety, depression, cravings, cognitive effects

The 10% Weekly Reduction Protocol

The evidence-based tapering approach involves reducing total daily dose by 10% every 7 days:

  1. Establish baseline: Measure and record your exact daily intake using a digital scale (0.1g accuracy)
  2. Calculate reduction: Multiply daily dose by 0.9 for your new weekly target
  3. Divide doses: Split daily amount across your normal dosing schedule
  4. Hold if needed: If symptoms emerge, hold current dose until stable before continuing
  5. Slower at low doses: Below 5g/day, consider 5% reductions every 1-2 weeks

Example 20g/day taper: Week 1: 18g → Week 2: 16.2g → Week 3: 14.6g → Week 4: 13.1g... continuing until cessation

Supportive Supplements

  • Magnesium glycinate (400-800mg/day): Reduces RLS and muscle tension
  • Vitamin C sodium ascorbate (megadose protocol): 5,000-25,000mg/day in divided doses during acute phase
  • Black seed oil (1-2 tsp/day): May reduce cravings and anxiety
  • L-theanine (200-400mg/day): For sleep and relaxation
  • Ashwagandha (300-600mg/day): Cortisol modulation and stress reduction

pillarSections.title: Safety Concerns & Side Effects
pillarSections.content:
Documented Deaths

The CDC documented 91 overdose deaths involving kratom from 2016-2017. While most cases involved polysubstance use, kratom was identified as a contributing factor. A 2025 Neurology study identified 113 kratom-induced seizures from Poison Control data (2011-2017), with risk elevated in concentrated 7-OH products.

Serious Adverse Events

  • Seizures: Increasing reports, especially with extract products. Standard urinalysis does not detect kratom; diagnosis often delayed 4+ days.
  • Hepatotoxicity: Rare but documented liver injury in chronic users requiring hospitalization.
  • Cardiac events: Case reports of tachycardia and arrhythmia at high doses.
  • Respiratory depression: Possible when combined with other CNS depressants.

Common Side Effects

SystemEffects
GastrointestinalNausea, vomiting, constipation, appetite suppression
NeurologicalDizziness, tremor, seizures (high dose), cognitive impairment
PsychologicalAnxiety, irritability, depression, insomnia
PhysicalDry mouth, sweating, weight loss, tolerance escalation

Drug Interactions

Kratom inhibits CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 enzymes, potentially increasing levels of medications metabolized by these pathways. Dangerous combinations include:

  • Opioids (respiratory depression risk)
  • Benzodiazepines (enhanced sedation)
  • Alcohol (CNS depression)
  • MAO inhibitors (hypertensive crisis potential)
  • Antidepressants (serotonin syndrome risk with some SSRIs)

Contamination Issues

The 2018 Salmonella outbreak infected 199 people across 41 states. Testing has also found kratom products contaminated with heavy metals, E. coli, and even synthetic opioids. The lack of FDA oversight means product quality varies dramatically.

faqs.question: Is kratom legal in my state in 2025?
faqs.answer: Kratom is fully banned in 7 states: Alabama, Arkansas, Indiana, Louisiana (as of Aug 1, 2025), Rhode Island, Vermont, and Wisconsin. It's legal with age restrictions (typically 21+) in 15+ KCPA states including Arizona, Florida, Georgia, and Texas. In remaining states, it's legal but unregulated. Check your specific state law before purchasing.

faqs.question: How long does kratom withdrawal last?
faqs.answer: Acute kratom withdrawal symptoms typically last 4-10 days, with peak intensity around days 3-4. Physical symptoms (muscle aches, GI issues, RLS) usually resolve within 7-10 days. Psychological symptoms (anxiety, depression, cravings) may persist for weeks in Post-Acute Withdrawal Syndrome (PAWS). Duration depends on dose, frequency, and individual metabolism.

faqs.question: Does kratom show up on a drug test?
faqs.answer: Standard 5-panel and 12-panel drug tests do NOT detect kratom. However, specialized tests for mitragynine exist and are increasingly used by probation offices, pain management clinics, and some employers. Kratom is detectable in urine for 5-7 days, blood for 24-48 hours, and hair for up to 90 days.

faqs.question: Can you die from kratom withdrawal?
faqs.answer: There are no documented deaths solely from kratom withdrawal. Unlike alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, kratom withdrawal does not typically cause seizures. However, severe dehydration from vomiting/diarrhea is a risk, and psychological distress including suicidal ideation has been reported. Medical supervision is recommended for heavy users.

faqs.question: What is the safest way to quit kratom?
faqs.answer: The safest approach is a gradual taper: reduce your dose by 10% every 7 days until cessation. Use a digital scale for accuracy. Supportive supplements (magnesium, vitamin C, black seed oil) can help manage symptoms. For heavy users (>20g/day) or those with complications, medical supervision with potential buprenorphine bridge therapy may be appropriate.

faqs.question: Is kratom an opioid?
faqs.answer: Kratom is classified as an 'atypical opioid.' Its primary alkaloids (mitragynine, 7-hydroxymitragynine) act on mu-opioid receptors like traditional opioids, but with additional activity at adrenergic, serotonergic, and other receptors. This creates both opioid-like effects (pain relief, sedation, withdrawal) and unique properties (stimulation at low doses). It produces physiological dependence and withdrawal similar to opioids.

substances.name: SARMs (Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Unapproved drugs - cannot be sold as dietary supplements. Felony charges for distribution.

stateRestrictions.Military: ALL SARMs on DOD Prohibited List

healthRisks.description: Multiple felony convictions for SARM distribution (2024-2025). Criminal risk to suppliers AND users.
Testosterone suppression requiring Post-Cycle Therapy. Unknown long-term effects.

substances.description: SARMs are synthetic drugs that bind to androgen receptors, claiming to build muscle selectively. They are unapproved drugs with unknown long-term risks, often contaminated or mislabeled, and carry serious legal consequences.
substances.mechanism: Bind to androgen receptors in muscle tissue, stimulating anabolic (muscle-building) effects. Claimed to be selective for muscle vs. prostate, but this selectivity is not proven in humans.
substances.history: Developed by pharmaceutical companies in the 1990s for muscle wasting diseases. None have been FDA approved. Proliferated in the supplement industry as 'research chemicals' to skirt regulations.
substances.whyBanned: Unapproved drugs with unknown long-term risks. FDA cannot ensure safety. Products often contaminated or mislabeled. Active criminal enforcement.
substances.metaTitle: SARMs - Why They're Illegal, Health Risks & Legal Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why SARMs are illegal unapproved drugs, the criminal penalties, health risks, and discover safe legal alternatives for muscle building.

substances.name: Ephedrine
substances.legalStatusDetails: Banned as dietary supplement ingredient since 2004. Landmark FDA ban case.

healthRisks.description: 155 deaths attributed to ephedra products (FDA count, 1995-2004). 10,000+ adverse event reports.
Heart attacks, strokes, arrhythmias, hypertensive crisis documented.

substances.description: Ephedrine is a sympathomimetic alkaloid that was widely used in weight loss and energy supplements until banned in 2004 after causing 155 deaths. This landmark case established modern FDA supplement oversight.
substances.mechanism: Alpha and beta-adrenergic agonist. Stimulates heart rate, blood pressure, and thermogenesis. Similar to adrenaline in effects.
substances.history: Used in traditional Chinese medicine for thousands of years. Became popular in US supplements in the 1990s. FDA banned after documenting 155 deaths. This case drove development of modern supplement regulations.
substances.whyBanned: Unacceptable cardiovascular risk. Risk-benefit analysis showed benefits do not justify mortality risk. 155 deaths documented before ban.
substances.metaTitle: Ephedrine (Ephedra) - Why It's Banned, 155 Deaths & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Ephedrine was banned after 155 deaths, its dangerous cardiovascular effects, and discover safe legal alternatives for weight loss and energy.

substances.name: Clenbuterol
substances.legalStatusDetails: NOT approved for human use in USA. Approved only for veterinary use (horses).

healthRisks.description: Cardiac hypertrophy, arrhythmia, electrolyte imbalances. Limited human safety data.

substances.description: Clenbuterol is a beta-2 agonist approved only for veterinary use in horses. It is used illegally in bodybuilding for fat loss and muscle preservation. Not studied extensively in humans.
substances.mechanism: Beta-2 agonist - increases metabolism and fat mobilization. Also increases muscle protein synthesis. Causes cardiac hypertrophy with chronic use.
substances.history: Developed as a bronchodilator. Approved for veterinary use in some countries. Used in bodybuilding communities since the 1980s. Food contamination incidents in Europe (2013).
substances.whyBanned: Not approved for human use. Veterinary drug only. Cardiovascular risks exceed any potential benefits. No human safety data.
substances.metaTitle: Clenbuterol - Why It's Illegal for Humans & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Clenbuterol is only approved for horses, the cardiovascular dangers, and discover safe legal alternatives for fat loss.

substances.name: Cardarine (GW501516)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Never FDA approved. Development abandoned due to cancer risk at ALL tested doses.

healthRisks.description: CANCER RISK - Caused multiple cancer types in animal studies at ALL tested doses. Development abandoned by GSK.

contraindications: Everyone - not safe for human use
substances.description: Cardarine (GW501516) is a PPAR delta agonist that was abandoned during drug development after causing cancer in animal studies at ALL tested doses. One of the most dangerous compounds still sold online.
substances.mechanism: Activates PPAR delta, increases fatty acid oxidation and endurance capacity. Also promotes cancer cell growth in multiple organ systems.
substances.history: Developed by GlaxoSmithKline for metabolic diseases. Development abandoned after 2-year animal studies showed cancer at all doses. Still sold illegally online as 'research chemical'.
substances.whyBanned: Cancer risk at ALL tested doses in animal models. Development abandoned by manufacturer due to unacceptable cancer risk. Never safe for human use.
substances.metaTitle: Cardarine (GW501516) - Cancer Risk Warning & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: CRITICAL WARNING: Cardarine caused cancer at ALL doses in studies. Learn why GSK abandoned it and discover safe legal alternatives for endurance.

substances.name: Nandrolone (Deca-Durabolin)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Schedule III controlled substance. Illegal without prescription. Felony possession.

healthRisks.description: Illegal possession is a felony. Most supply is from black market/counterfeits.
Testosterone suppression, testicular atrophy, requires PCT. Virilization in women.

substances.description: Nandrolone is an anabolic androgenic steroid classified as a Schedule III controlled substance. Illegal possession is a felony. Most gym supply is from black market with unknown purity.
substances.mechanism: Synthetic androgen. Binds to androgen receptors, stimulating protein synthesis and muscle growth. Suppresses natural testosterone production.
substances.history: Developed in the 1950s for medical use. Classified as Schedule III controlled substance under the Anabolic Steroid Control Act. Still prescribed rarely for anemia and wasting diseases.
substances.whyBanned: Controlled substance with abuse potential and significant health risks. Illegal without prescription. Black market products often contaminated.
substances.metaTitle: Nandrolone (Deca) - Schedule III Controlled Substance & Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Nandrolone is a Schedule III controlled substance (felony possession), health risks, and discover safe legal alternatives for muscle building.

substances.name: DMHA (Octodrine)
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA issued 12 warning letters in April 2019. Products containing DMHA are adulterated.

healthRisks.description: Supplements contained 72±7.5 mg per serving, more than twice historical pharmaceutical doses. Causes hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia.

substances.description: DMHA (2-aminoisoheptane) is a synthetic stimulant originally developed in the 1950s as an inhaled nasal decongestant—never approved for oral use. It emerged as a DMAA alternative in pre-workout supplements after the 2013 DMAA ban.
substances.mechanism: Sympathomimetic amine that stimulates norepinephrine release, causing increased heart rate, blood pressure, and thermogenesis.
substances.history: Originally patented in the 1950s as a nasal decongestant. Resurfaced in supplements around 2016 as 'DMAA alternative'. FDA cracked down in 2019 with 12 warning letters to companies including Hi-Tech Pharmaceuticals.
substances.whyBanned: FDA determined DMHA is an unsafe food additive. Never tested for oral human use at supplement doses. Products are adulterated under DSHEA.
substances.metaTitle: DMHA (Octodrine) - FDA Banned Stimulant & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why DMHA (2-aminoisoheptane, Octodrine) was banned by FDA in 2019, its dangerous cardiovascular effects, and discover safe legal pre-workout alternatives.

substances.name: BMPEA
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA issued 5 warning letters in April 2015. BMPEA is a synthetic adulterant, NOT naturally present in Acacia rigidula despite label claims.

healthRisks.description: Swedish case report documented cerebral hemorrhage in female athlete after consuming supplement with 290 mg BMPEA (unlabeled).

substances.description: BMPEA (β-methylphenylethylamine) is a positional isomer of amphetamine. FDA research in 2013 established it is NOT naturally present in Acacia rigidula—despite label claims, it is a synthetic adulterant with approximately 1/10th amphetamine potency.
substances.mechanism: Substrate-type releaser at norepinephrine transporters. Structural isomer of amphetamine with similar but less potent stimulant effects on the central nervous system.
substances.history: Marketed as 'natural' Acacia rigidula extract in numerous supplements. FDA scientifically proved it was a synthetic adulterant in 2013. Warning letters issued to 5 companies in April 2015.
substances.whyBanned: Synthetic stimulant fraudulently labeled as natural plant extract. Never approved for human consumption. Amphetamine-like cardiovascular effects.
substances.metaTitle: BMPEA - Amphetamine Analog Banned by FDA & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: BMPEA is an amphetamine isomer found as synthetic adulterant in 'Acacia rigidula' supplements. Learn why FDA banned it and find safe legal alternatives.

substances.name: Tianeptine
substances.legalStatusDetails: Scheduled in 12+ states including Alabama (Schedule I), Florida (Schedule I), Michigan (Schedule II), Ohio (Schedule I). FDA consumer warnings issued 2022-2025.

healthRisks.description: CDC documented poison center calls increasing from 11 total (2000-2013) to 391 in 2023. Effects mimic opioid toxicity and withdrawal. Users ingesting 1.3 to 250 times typical pharmaceutical doses.

substances.description: Tianeptine is an atypical tricyclic antidepressant that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. Known as 'gas station heroin' due to its availability at convenience stores and gas stations, and its severe opioid-like effects at high doses. Commonly sold as Zaza, Tianaa, Neptune's Fix, and TD Red.
substances.mechanism: Mu-opioid receptor agonist causing euphoria and analgesia similar to traditional opioids. At high doses (commonly seen in abuse), produces full opioid toxicity including respiratory depression and severe physical dependence with life-threatening withdrawal.
substances.history: Prescription drug in Europe, Asia, and Latin America since the 1980s for depression. Never FDA approved. Emerged in US as 'dietary supplement' around 2010. Multiple states scheduled after documented deaths and an addiction epidemic. Known as 'gas station heroin' crisis.
substances.whyBanned: Opioid-like effects causing severe addiction, overdose, and death. Products sold at doses up to 250 times therapeutic levels. 'Gas station heroin' epidemic with opioid withdrawal syndrome.
substances.metaTitle: Tianeptine (Zaza, Gas Station Heroin) - Dangers, Deaths & Safer Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Tianeptine (Zaza, Tianaa, Neptune's Fix) is 'gas station heroin' causing severe opioid addiction and deaths. Learn the dangers, withdrawal symptoms, and find safe legal alternatives.

substances.name: Adrafinil
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA classified as unapproved new drug. Criminal prosecutions with prison sentences for sellers. In 2023, Nootropics Depot CEO was sentenced to prison and ordered to forfeit $2.4 million.

healthRisks.description: Liver enzyme elevations with prolonged use. The prodrug form was voluntarily discontinued in France in 2011 due to 'unfavorable risk-benefit ratio' from liver concerns.
2023: Nootropics Depot CEO sentenced to prison, $2.4 million forfeiture for selling adrafinil, tianeptine, and phenibut.

substances.description: Adrafinil is a prodrug of modafinil, a DEA Schedule IV controlled substance. It requires hepatic metabolism to produce the active drug, placing significant strain on the liver. Selling adrafinil has resulted in criminal prosecution and prison time for supplement sellers.
substances.mechanism: Metabolized by the liver into modafinil (Schedule IV). Increases dopamine and norepinephrine neurotransmission, promoting wakefulness. Hepatotoxic due to extensive first-pass metabolism required for activation.
substances.history: Developed in France in the 1970s by Lafon Laboratories for narcolepsy treatment. Voluntarily discontinued in France in 2011 due to liver risks and availability of modafinil. US supplement sellers prosecuted criminally in 2023.
substances.whyBanned: Prodrug of DEA Schedule IV controlled substance (modafinil). Classified as unapproved new drug by FDA. Hepatotoxic. Active criminal enforcement with prison sentences.
substances.metaTitle: Adrafinil - Modafinil Prodrug, Liver Damage, Prison Sentences & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Adrafinil is a prodrug of modafinil that causes liver damage. Learn why sellers are going to prison and find safe legal nootropic alternatives for focus and wakefulness.

substances.name: Phenylpiracetam
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA classifies as unapproved new drug. WADA prohibited since 1998—the ONLY racetam on WADA's banned list. Named in 2022-2023 criminal enforcement actions.

healthRisks.description: Multiple doping cases including Russian Olympic biathlete Olga Pyleva (2006 silver medal stripped). Named in 2022-2023 US criminal enforcement actions against supplement sellers.

substances.description: Phenylpiracetam (Carphedon) is the ONLY racetam on WADA's prohibited list, banned in-competition since 1998. It's a prescription drug in Russia for cerebrovascular deficiency and depression. FDA classifies it as an unapproved drug in the US, and it has been named in criminal enforcement actions.
substances.mechanism: Racetam nootropic with an added phenyl group that significantly increases potency and adds stimulant-like effects. Enhances dopamine and norepinephrine activity beyond other racetams.
substances.history: Developed in Russia in 1983 for Soviet cosmonauts to combat stress and cold tolerance. Approved in Russia as prescription drug Phenotropil in 2003. Multiple Olympic doping scandals. US criminal enforcement 2022-2023.
substances.whyBanned: Unapproved drug with significant stimulant properties. The ONLY WADA-banned racetam due to performance enhancing effects. Career-ending for competitive athletes.
substances.metaTitle: Phenylpiracetam (Carphedon) - WADA Banned, Only Banned Racetam & Legal Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Phenylpiracetam is the ONLY racetam banned by WADA since 1998. Learn why athletes lose Olympic medals and careers, and find safe legal nootropic alternatives.

substances.name: Ostarine (MK-2866)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Unapproved drug—cannot legally be sold as supplement or for human consumption. 20+ drug-induced liver injury cases documented in medical literature since 2020. Active criminal enforcement.

healthRisks.description: Over 20 drug-induced liver injury (DILI) cases documented in NIH PubMed medical literature since 2020. Cholestatic liver injury pattern.
Significant testosterone suppression requiring Post-Cycle Therapy. Development discontinued after failing to improve muscle strength in cancer patient trials.

substances.description: Ostarine (MK-2866/Enobosarm) is the most commonly detected SARM in both doping tests and supplement adulteration testing. Development by GTx was discontinued after failing Phase 3 clinical trials to improve muscle strength in cancer patients. Over 20 documented liver injury cases.
substances.mechanism: Selective Androgen Receptor Modulator that binds to androgen receptors primarily in muscle and bone tissue. Despite claimed selectivity, causes significant testosterone suppression requiring PCT.
substances.history: Developed by GTx Inc. for cancer-related muscle wasting. Failed Phase 3 clinical trials. Most detected SARM globally with over 230 positive doping tests since 2012. Frequently found as undeclared adulterant in supplements.
substances.whyBanned: Unapproved drug causing documented liver injury cases. Development abandoned after failing efficacy trials. Most common SARM in doping violations and supplement adulteration.
substances.metaTitle: Ostarine (MK-2866) - Liver Injury Risk, Failed Trials & Legal Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Ostarine (MK-2866) causes liver damage with 20+ documented cases. Learn why this SARM failed clinical trials and find safe legal muscle-building alternatives.

substances.name: Andarine (S-4)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Unapproved drug. Development discontinued in favor of ostarine due to unique and concerning vision side effects.

healthRisks.description: Unique and concerning side effect: visual disturbances including yellow-tinted vision (everything appears yellow) and significant difficulty adjusting to darkness/night blindness.

substances.description: Andarine (S-4) is a SARM with a unique and particularly concerning side effect: vision disturbances including yellow-tinted vision and significant difficulty adjusting to darkness. Development was discontinued in favor of ostarine due to these vision problems.
substances.mechanism: Binds to androgen receptors in muscle tissue but ALSO binds to receptors in the eye's retina, causing the characteristic yellow vision and night blindness. Less selective than originally claimed.
substances.history: Early SARM developed by GTx Inc. Discontinued during development due to the unexpected and concerning vision side effects. Development efforts shifted to ostarine instead.
substances.whyBanned: Unapproved drug with unique vision impairment side effects that could endanger users (driving, operating machinery). Never completed clinical development due to safety concerns.
substances.metaTitle: Andarine (S-4) - Yellow Vision, Night Blindness & Safer Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Andarine (S-4) causes yellow-tinted vision and night blindness. Learn why this SARM was abandoned and find safe legal muscle-building alternatives.

substances.name: Yohimbine/Yohimbe
substances.legalStatusDetails: Yohimbine HCl is an FDA-approved PRESCRIPTION drug. Yohimbe bark extract sold as supplement but with 5.81x higher serious outcome rate than average poisonings.

stateRestrictions.US: Yohimbine HCl = Prescription Only; Yohimbe bark = High-risk supplement

healthRisks.description: California Poison Control System study (2000-2006): 238 yohimbine cases with 5.81x higher odds of serious outcomes than average poison exposures. Documented cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, seizures, and acute renal failure.

substances.description: Yohimbine is an α2-adrenergic receptor antagonist from yohimbe bark. The pure compound (yohimbine HCl) is an FDA-approved prescription drug for erectile dysfunction. Bark extracts sold as supplements have highly variable yohimbine content (up to 154% variation) with inadequate safety labeling and 5.81x higher serious outcome rate.
substances.mechanism: Blocks α2-adrenergic receptors, causing increased norepinephrine release throughout the body. Results in elevated blood pressure, heart rate, and anxiety. Also affects fat mobilization.
substances.history: Traditional use in West Africa as aphrodisiac. Yohimbine HCl approved as prescription drug for ED. Bark supplements are poorly regulated with a 2015 analysis of 49 supplements showing highly variable and often undisclosed yohimbine content.
substances.whyBanned: Pure yohimbine requires prescription. Bark supplements have dangerous content variability and 5.81x higher odds of serious poisoning outcomes including cardiac events and seizures.
substances.metaTitle: Yohimbine/Yohimbe - 5.81x More Dangerous, Heart Risks & Safer Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Yohimbine causes cardiac arrhythmias with 5.81x more serious poisonings than average. Learn the risks of yohimbe supplements and find safe legal fat loss alternatives.

substances.name: Higenamine
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA warning letters May 2022—determined to be a New Dietary Ingredient requiring premarket notification (none submitted). WADA prohibited at ALL times since 2017.

healthRisks.description: WADA prohibited since 2017 under S3 Beta-2 Agonists. Reporting threshold: 10 ng/mL in urine. Caused UEFA footballer Mamadou Sakho's suspension in 2016. Multiple athlete career-ending suspensions.

substances.description: Higenamine is a β2-adrenergic agonist found naturally in lotus seeds, Nandina domestica, aconite root, and beetroot. FDA determined it requires New Dietary Ingredient notification (none submitted). WADA banned since 2017—has ended athletic careers including UEFA footballer Mamadou Sakho.
substances.mechanism: Activates β2-adrenergic receptors causing bronchodilation, increased heart rate, and thermogenesis. Effects similar to ephedrine and other banned β2 agonists.
substances.history: Traditional use in Chinese medicine (lotus seeds). Emerged in pre-workout supplements around 2015. WADA added to prohibited list effective January 2017. FDA issued warning letters May 2022 for missing NDI notifications.
substances.whyBanned: New Dietary Ingredient without required FDA premarket notification. WADA prohibited as β2-agonist at all times. Career-ending for competitive athletes in any sport.
substances.metaTitle: Higenamine - WADA Banned, Career-Ending for Athletes & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Higenamine is banned by WADA and flagged by FDA. Learn why athletes lose careers over this ingredient and find safe legal pre-workout alternatives.

substances.name: Vinpocetine
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA June 2019 critical pregnancy warning—NIH found clear evidence it causes miscarriages and fetal harm. FDA tentatively ruled vinpocetine ineligible for dietary supplement status.

stateRestrictions.US: FDA Pregnancy Warning - Tentatively Ineligible for Supplements

healthRisks.description: NIH National Toxicology Program found clear evidence vinpocetine triggers miscarriages and causes fetal harm in animal studies at blood levels similar to humans after taking a SINGLE dose.

substances.description: Vinpocetine is a synthetic derivative of vincamine used for cognitive enhancement. FDA issued a CRITICAL pregnancy warning in June 2019: 'Women who are pregnant or who could become pregnant should not take vinpocetine' due to NIH evidence of miscarriage and fetal harm at normal supplement doses.
substances.mechanism: Phosphodiesterase inhibitor that increases cerebral blood flow. Also affects fetal development, causing pregnancy loss and developmental abnormalities in offspring.
substances.history: Synthesized from periwinkle plant (vinca) alkaloids. Prescription drug in Europe and Japan for cerebrovascular disorders. FDA issued critical pregnancy warning June 2019 after NIH National Toxicology Program findings. Tentatively ruled ineligible for supplement status.
substances.whyBanned: Causes miscarriages and fetal harm at NORMAL supplement doses—effects seen at blood levels achieved after a single dose. FDA explicitly warns ALL women of childbearing age to avoid. Tentatively ruled ineligible for dietary supplements.
substances.metaTitle: Vinpocetine - CAUSES MISCARRIAGE, FDA Pregnancy Warning & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: CRITICAL: FDA warns vinpocetine causes miscarriages and fetal harm. Women of childbearing age should NOT take it. Find safe legal cognitive enhancement alternatives.

substances.name: Picamilon
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA issued 5 warning letters in November 2015 determining picamilon does NOT meet the dietary ingredient definition—it is a 'unique chemical entity synthesized from dietary ingredients' that crosses the blood-brain barrier.

stateRestrictions.US: Not a Dietary Ingredient - Products Adulterated

healthRisks.description: Testing found supplements containing 2.7 to 721.5 mg per daily serving—compared to Russian prescription doses of only 50-100 mg. Extreme and dangerous variability.

substances.description: Picamilon is a synthetic niacin-GABA prodrug that crosses the blood-brain barrier intact and accumulates in the brain as a separate chemical entity. FDA ruled it is NOT a dietary ingredient because it's a 'unique chemical entity synthesized from dietary ingredients'—not the same as taking GABA and niacin separately.
substances.mechanism: Crosses the blood-brain barrier intact, then is cleaved by brain enzymes into niacin and GABA. This provides GABA effects in the brain that are NOT achievable from oral GABA supplements (which don't cross the BBB).
substances.history: Developed in the Soviet Union in 1969. Prescription drug in Russia for anxiety, cerebrovascular disease, and depression. FDA banned as a supplement ingredient in November 2015. Despite ruling, continued appearing in supplements through 2020.
substances.whyBanned: Not a dietary ingredient—synthetic prodrug designed to cross the BBB. Extreme dosage variability in supplements (2.7-721.5 mg vs 50-100 mg prescription). Chemical manipulation to bypass normal GABA limitations.
substances.metaTitle: Picamilon - FDA Banned Synthetic GABA Prodrug & Legal Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Picamilon is a synthetic GABA prodrug banned by FDA in 2015—not a legal supplement. Learn why it's not the same as GABA and find safe legal relaxation alternatives.

substances.name: AMP Citrate (DMBA)
substances.legalStatusDetails: FDA issued 14 warning letters in April 2015. Never tested in human clinical trials—health effects entirely unknown.

healthRisks.description: NEVER evaluated in human clinical trials. Supplements contained 13-120 mg per serving—health effects are entirely unknown. This is a completely untested synthetic stimulant.

substances.description: AMP Citrate (DMBA/1,3-Dimethylbutylamine) is a synthetic stimulant that was NEVER tested in human clinical trials. FDA issued 14 warning letters in April 2015 to companies including VPX Sports. The health effects are entirely unknown—this is essentially an untested experimental drug.
